docs.lead_paragraph: Retirement at age 65, the dream proffered to working Americans for a half century and more, is fading under the pressure of economic and social trends that appear irreversible. Except for a relatively small proportion with substantial resources, inherited or self-acquired, the generation of Americans now beginning to turn 35 can no longer expect to enjoy reasonable financial security if they stop working when they reach 60 or 65. Early retirement, encouraged by some employers and welcomed by many employees in recent, more prosperous times, is expected to become a less and less attractive option for those passing 55 or 60, until in 30 years the option is virtually foreclosed. The majority of Americans may have to work full time until they near 70 and, in some cases, part-time after that. Need to Lower Expectations This sobering picture is just beginning to emerge, according to Government and academic authorities in the varied fields involving aging, even as Congress resumes grappling with its most immediate manifestation - the financial crisis in the Social Security system. In 30 years, when the swollen post-World War II generation is beginning to retire, its full impact will be staggeringly clear.

headline.main: GOAL OF RETIRING AT 65 RECEDES UNDER ECONOMIC PRESSURE AND POPULATION CURVE
